title: Effect of Avatar Head Movement on Communication Behaviour, Experience of Presence and Conversation Success in Triadic Conversations
author: Angelika Kothe (Carl von Ossietzky Universität Oldenburg), Volker Hohmann (Carl von Ossietzky Universität Oldenburg), Giso Grimm (Carl von Ossietzky Universität Oldenburg), ...
relevance_why: The study explores real-time communication dynamics in virtual environments, which could inform audio-visual integration techniques in Haohe Liu's audio processing research.
background: Investigating the influence of animated head movements in virtual conversations on participants' communication behaviors and interactions within a controlled environment.
contribution: This paper introduces an evaluation of animated avatars in virtual conversations to solve issues of communication barriers, achieving insights into the impact on speech behavior and conversation success.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Traditional studies on communication do not consider the effects of nonverbal cues like head movements in virtual settings.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work uniquely employs animated head movements of avatars derived from real-time data to enhance realism in virtual conversations.

key_innovation: Utilizes transmitted head movements of real interlocutors to animate avatars, significantly improving perceived realism and conversational effectiveness in virtual settings.
real_world_impact: The findings could enhance the design of virtual communication tools and improve user experiences in applications such as virtual conferencing, gaming, and therapy.
limitations: The study's reliance on a small participant group may limit the generalizability of the results.

new_terms.triadic conversations: **Triadic conversations** involve interactions between three participants, allowing for the study of turn-taking and attentional shifts among interlocutors.
